reviewText:
Command and Conquer does it again with another great installment onto the Red Alert series. Although not as good as its predecessor C&C: RA3 continues to offer no need for builders and no worry of controlling population.

Gameplay:
Unlike past Red Alerts I only played about one skirmish as I did not find the AI as enjoyable as the predecessors. This Red Alert offers some interesting new teams and resource harvesting concepts which seem different than before. Like in the past Red Alert games the Russians and Allies are pretty much the same basic strategy type, while the third team offers a fresh new tactics. Similar to past Red Alerts to expand bases (when playing as either Allies or Soviets) you can build Mobile Construction Vehicles. But, unlike past Red alerts they have also added the ability for Prospectors (allied ore miners) to deploy into Command Centers which allow you to expand to nearby areas mitigating large costs. The USSR can build “Sputnik” which can also deploy into a command center. Both of these units allow for cheaper base expansion. This is different for the Japanese whose buildings are built by transforming vehicles into buildings and thus are not limited to base parameters.

Campaign:
The campaign took me about 21 hours to complete (that includes Allies, Russians, and Rising Sun missions). Interestingly the campaigns intertwine and in some instances you play the same missions but just as the opposing team, which I sort of liked. In the case of this game the missions are not exactly gripping, but that is the case with all strategy games. The campaign offers a great composition of actors which make you laugh, gasp, and reminisce in the old days when you first sat down and played Red Alert. Some of the missions are very quick and last no time at all while others can last a couple hours.

Results:
If you are expecting something just like the second Red Alert then you will be disappointed. There is only one Yuri and his revenge was an epic adventure that could only be told once. If you are interested in playing a strategy game that brings Red Alert on a new adventure then this is a game worth checking out. With an amazing intro song to boot and epic campaign cut scenes that you won't forget. Red Alert 3 really takes Westwood’s dream into action: hot babes who flirt with you throughout your entire game and keep your spirits bolstered with cheesy lines.

Pros:
+Great campaign with fun dialogue and amazing cut scenes.
+New Empire of the Rising Sun team which brings all new tactics to the game
+Campaign missions that don't just require you to continually build a base over and over again, but rather test you through a variety of scenarios.
+Epic main menu music that just makes you want to jump right into the Russian campaign.
+It has been 18 years and Tanya still hasn't aged over 30... a mystery? Or did someone use the chronosphere?

Cons:
-Its not Red Alert 2 (that game already existed, if you want that game you may want to go find the disk from your shelf)
-Some campaign missions can run rather long, while others last about 10 minutes. (Some missions took me up to three hours).
-Poor movement AI can cause units to not exactly act how you want them too.

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
NOTE: I have played this game extensively, but not on Steam.

INTRODUCTION:Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a Real Time Strategy (RTS) game serving as the third installment of the popular Command & Conquer series.  It features a rebooted story and a brand new faction called 'The Empire of the Rising Sun'.  However, unlike its predecessors,  Electronic Arts who acquired Westwood Studios, the original developers of the game, produced Red Alert 3.  It is one of the last few remaining franchises who use live action cutscenes which the series is known for.

Players once again take the role of the unknown commander who leads either the Allied Forces, the Soviet Army, or the newly resurrected Imperial Armed Forces to ultimate victory.

Red Alert 3's story starts with the Soviet Union in complete collapse after the events of Red Alert 2.  In an effort to stop the USSR's defeat, surviving Soviet leaders use a time machine to go back in history and erase Albert Einstein in order to prevent him from developing Allied technology.  Upon returning to the Present day however, they discover that without Einstein, nuclear technology was  never developed.  With this turn of events, this meant that the US never bombed Japan and the Empire never surrendered during World War 2.  Now the Empire has risen once more and poses a new threat to both the Soviets and the Allies prompting the hilarious line by actor Peter Stormare as Dr. Gregor Zelinsky: “We now have...two mortal enemies?”

PROS:+ Colorful visuals and very nice graphics with good use of Physx technology
+ New 'Empire of the Rising Sun' faction is fun to play featuring highly advanced, extremely versatile, very expensive, and unhealthily suicidal units (ex. Tsunami Tank: “HA! Give us a good death”  Imperial Warrior:  “Death before defeat!” Shogun Battleship:  “Ramming speed!” Yari Sub:  “We're taking you with us!”
+ Fun campaign for all 3 factions
+ Hilarious, Hammy, Cheesy but overall good voice acting
+ Humorous and entertaining Tutorial
+ All units for all factions now have secondary abilities
+ Co-op campaign
+ Very nice Music and Sounds

CONS:- The very colorful art-style that could cause headaches for some people
- Some low polygon models, low resolution shadows, and poor textures can be seen here and there
- Short campaign for each faction
- Story is shallow and uses way to many cliche elements from the previous Red Alert 2
- Occasional pathfinding problems
- Balance issues with some of the units
- Some outstanding bugs that was never fixed (for some reason, changing the graphics quality and  resolution at the same time MAY cause a crash)
- Despite EA's vast resources and use of big name actors like Peter Stormare and George Takei, I can't help but feel that they were not able to live up to the standard of Westwood.
- Broken multiplayer on Steam (No idea if it works in Origin)

CONCLUSION:GREAT RTS GAME.  Although it does not fully capture the magic of Red Alert 2, Red Alert 3 still delivers a great fast paced experience for RTS fans looking for a quick fix.  The campaign is fun with a story that is easy to follow but uses a lot of cliche plot elements.  The Soundtrack is excellent and the over-the-top, hammy, and cheesy voice acting are very entertaining.  Multiplayer is also fun if you're looking for a casual RTS experience since the AI does pose a challenge on higher difficulties.  In addition, new game mechanics such as the secondary abilities and the new faction spices up the action.

Now we come on whether or not I recommend this game.  If you're in this for the single player experience, sure I can RECOMMEND this game easily.  If you're in this for the multiplayer experience, I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game here on Steam because for some reason the Servers are broken so you're better off purchasing this in EA's Origin Platform.

reviewText:
Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a real-time strategy game and obviously the follow-up to Red Alert 2. While I absolutely loved Red Alert 2 I can't say the same for this title.

First, there are some things Red Alert 3 does well. The storyline is as cheesy as it comes and that is what fans expect and love. It is also great that the game has actors like Tim Curry, George Takei and David Hasselhoff, who really seem to enjoy performing the B-movie-like storyline.

However, Red Alert 3 has many problems compared to its predecessor. The units have a cartoonish look to them and look like child's toys. Many of them look so over the top that it is just ridiculous. Also, the weapon's effects and sounds don't convey any impact, further reinforcing that impression.

The gameplay itself comes off as very hectic because units cannot take any damage, no matter the unit type. Even the biggest tanks and ships give off the impression of being made of paper. They get destroyed within seconds leaving no room for actual micromanagement. The problem is that the game wants the player to micromanage since every unit has some sort of special ability. There is not much room to use them however and I would have preferred not having them at all except the toggled abilites. The units' AI is also pretty bad. If the enemy has a slightly longer range they will refrain from retaliating and just get destroyed. Anti-air weaponry is extremely underwhelming in this game. Often building turrets don't seem to make no sense at all. Even if you have a solid turret setup there is just not much use in defending since there are so many units that can destroy your base from huge distances. If the enemy uses aircraft they will still destroy your base because there is no defense that will keep them from destroying at least one target in every run.

Red Alert 3 features a computer controlled partner in every campaign mission. This partner can be replaced by a human player and while I appreciate the idea of making the whole campaign able to be played coop it just doesn't work. The computer partner is highly unreliable in its performance. In some missions it will basically win the mission by itself with you struggling to keep up with the pace and in some missions it will be literally useless. During the last mission of the Rising Sun campaign my AI partner was actually unable to even defend its own base. When I didn't continually sent units there my partner would just be annihilated within a few minutes. All of this while I had my own problems, being hammered by airstrikes, superweapons and ground troops.

The campaign should come with a trigger warning (pun intended) because all missions are heavily built around triggers that you most of the time cannot see coming. However you need to be prepared for them because if you're not you have basically lost. There is no reaction time since the game is fast and units and buildings cannot withstand any damage. It's bad design if you can only win by being able to see into the future. If you have run your head into the wall a few times you will know the triggers and it basically becomes a minigame of avoiding those. One of the worst examples is from the Rising Sun campaign. At one point you will be confronted with a huge enemy fleet and have to hold out until your battleships arrive. When they arrive it is still not enough to destroy the enemie's base but you absolutely need to destroy all their shipyards. Why you ask? Because the AI will start producing an indefinite amount of aircraft carriers and since anti-air turrets are horribly weak you will lose.

Red Alert 3 is not a horrible game but is has so many shortcomings compared to its predecessor that I cannot recommend it at all.

P.S.: If you liked the Tanya from Red Alert 2 you will be severely disappointed.

reviewText:
This is, to my mind, the best Command & Conquer game out there. Some complain about the blatant fanservice with respect to the use of well-edowed female actrices in the hammy videos, while others believe that Red Alert 3 has gone too far with respect to the silliness inherent in the series (i.e. the use of war bears by the Soviets and the mecha-inspired units in the army of the Empire of the Rising Sun). To me, all that stuff is simply silly fluff that shouldn't be taken seriously.

What should be taken seriously is the gameplay. The game is a refined version of the Command & Conquer style of real-time strategy game: a simple economy (you build powerplants to power your structures and harvest ore to get money to buy more buildings and units) with an emphasis on the spectacle of battle. Units are fragile, so expect many of them to be destroyed more or less as soon  as you encounter enemy forces. Hard counters are used, which means that some units, for example, have no defences against air units, or are weak against certain types of infantry, and so forth. This means that reconaissance is as important if not more so as in other RTS games.

Red Alert 3 is more micro-heavy than most of the other games in the series. Each and every unit has a toggable special ability (hotkey F), and use of these special abilities will prove essential in most battles. Combined with the speed at which units move and their fragile nature, this means that games can get very hectic, very fast. It's for this reason that I mostly avoid multiplayer: I know that I won't be good enough to compete anyway. Instead, I stick to singleplayer and it's loads of fun.

The game has three factions and each of them gets their own campaign, with each campaign consisting of nine missions each. The different factions are the Allies, the Soviets, and a new third faction especially developed for this game, namely the Empire of the Rising Sun (essentially Japan). The Allies emphasize their air power, while the Soviets field relatively sturdy ground troops and can spit out a lot of units. The Empire is a high-tech faction with specialized units (remember: F is your friend!) and probably the most difficult to play by newcomers. The leaders of each of these factions are played by well-known actors: Vincent Pryce, Tim Curry, and George Takei, respectively.

I've put many hours into the disc version of the game before buying it anew on Steam and do not regret a single minute that I spent playing the game. The campaign is entertaining and can also be played fully in co-op mode. If you don't have any friends, an AI will take over. The AI sometimes really helps out during missions, but more often than not simply forms a distraction that the enemy AI will occupy itself with while you build your base and reinforce your army. If the campaign is not your cup of tea, you can always play skirmishes against the computer or go online (there is a replacement out there for GameSpy, so the online component does still work, thanks to the fans).

reviewText:
There are two things in particular that make this game: the humour, and the co-op. Truth be told, I haven't played through either of the previous Red Alert games, so I wouldn't know how this is as a sequel. However, on it's own, this game is very fun, especially if you play through it with a friend. Not a lot of RTS games offer co-op throughout their campaign, and it was very welcome as co-op is guaranteed to improve any game. The comedy of the game was also great. I'm not saying it's particularly hilarious, it's just that it's an RTS that doesn't take itself seriously, which again, not a lot of RTS games do. It does have it's moments though that are genuinely funny, especially from the live-action performances of Tim Curry, George Takei, and JK Simmons. The story is also appropriately absurd and great if you don't want to take yourself seriously.

Gameplay wise, there are much deeper RTS games to play besides this one. Again, don't dismiss it because of that, it's still fun, but if you are looking for a very strategic RTS, this isn't the one. Not to say the strategic element is completely lacking, the three factions all have their own play styles which can translate into having to alter your strategy depending on who you are playing as and who you are fighting. All three factions can also build on land, air, and water which also have their own strengths and weaknesses. Water is also prominently built into each map, so navies are actually quite useful, another thing that not a lot of other RTS games do. Like I said before though, the gameplay is good, just not great.

Great game if you like RTS games and want a loony experience with one of your friends.

This is a game that doesn't take itself very seriously and probably turned out better for it.

reviewText:
As a fan of Red Alert 2, I was pretty hyped for this game. When the reviews came out, it was clear it wasn't the same experience as before, so I held off purchase. But when it came to sale for the low, low price of €3, I couldn't resist picking it up. It can't be a bad deal for that price, right?

Wrong. The inclusion of an Allied AI commander clearly supposed to carry the single player campaign in absence of a multiplayer buddy just doesn't work. It's frustrating to have a lot of your fun depend on a dead weight ally. Single player campaign play is frustrating, and only really worth it for the FMV cutscenes. The casting choices are great, including the awesome George Takei as the Japanese Emperor. But, on that subject, the faction of Japan just doesn't feel right in Red Alert, and tries to steal the spotlight from the established factions in a way that just doesn't work. Red Alert's campy plots and cutscenes thrived on its mock Cold War feeling.

From a technical standpoint, it's a fine game. Units are diverse, mechanics are solid enough. Undoubtedly the strength of the game is in multiplayer, which I haven't tried. But it just doesn't feel like it's a proper Red Alert game. Plainly put, I wasn't having fun with this, and rarely have I been so disappointed in a purchase.

reviewText:
Gameplay:
Red alert 3 oversees an interesing  transition from RA2, incorporating numerous alternations to the gameplay that allows the game to be more tense as the designs shift more to what you will see in a serios RTS-- most prominently, ore becomes a confined resource which cannot be harvested exponentially by cramming your build order with harvesters. Units can be categorized into anti-infantry and anti-armor. Main battle tanks may be terrifyingly effective against armor yet at the same time they require five to six shots to kill some of the most cheapest infanty, which indeed is hard to grasp at first. As such, attacks emphasize on the cooperation of different units spamming only one type of unit would not bring you anywere. Micromanaging becomes vital through the concept of 'crushing levels' where infantry are subject to be crushed by incoming tanks while tanks are subject to be flattened by even bigger vehicles. Several secondary abilities and attack formations of the different factions also heavily rely on micromanaging.

The single player campaign is also incredibly entertaining. I loved the cutscenes shot in real person. The humorous plot is mildly funny and worth a laugh.

Graphics:
Absolutely brilliant special effects with breathtakingly beautiful water. Personally I prefer the rather vibrant hue in RA3 instead of  other CNC games or Starcraft. Antialiasing options lags the computer more than smoothing out the edges, however the game does not suffer from antialiasing issues much even without AA turned on.

Annoying bugs:
The pathfinding system is a total mess.
Sometimes units would take a full round trip around the building it just came out of before heading anywhere else.
Units getting stuck on the road for no reason.
Highly expensive naval fleet would randomly be stuck on the shoreline, becoming virtually worthless.
Units would line up and move single-filed, slowing each other down.
Nanocores of the Empire unable to deploy and stop en-route for no reason on certain maps

EA:
The experience for the game would be much smoother if it wasn't published by EA. RA3 had great multiplayer potential as with the introduction of the competitive aspects to the game. However, the servers in charge of hosting RA3 online closed down and there has only been a community supported server ever since, and the popularty of the RA3 community has been ever plummeting since. You won't find as much players nowadays as compared to when the gamespy servers were still online, and as a result matchmaking is almost impossible due to the tiny amount of players still playing the game.

Overall, the Red Alert 3 is a great game that could be great fun to play no matter by yourself or with others. However I certainly don't think that it is worth this price due to EA's unresponsible attitude towards this game. Buy it if you have some spare money to have fun with, but it is not on the must-have list.

reviewText:
I'm a pretty big fan of the Command and Conquer franchise, so I was very much looking forward to finally playing this, albeit years after its release.

Unfortunately, while playing this game, all I could think about was how much more fun the campaigns of previous installments were, particularly Red Alert 2.

The first Red Alert featured faceless pixelated troops that you'd throw en masse against your enemies. The second one took a completely different approach, with individual units being rather personalized and potentially extremely powerful (even GIs were a menace at Elite veterancy) and allowing you to wreck enemy bases with just a handful of units in the right spots (I remember being able to dismantle most bases in campaign mode with only 3 Legionnaires). The third installment seems to fit somewhere in between, but loses something to both.

Ah, good old Red Alert.

Nothing better than a RTS that is easy going with over the top plot and units and technologies. Comparing the three installments of this game the first one was the least over the top. It still had some seriousness from the original C&C, but had the basis for ‘over-the-top-ness’ with the idea of Soviet Union expanding into all of Europe. Oh, and there was time travel as well. The second RA didn’t disappoint and took a leap forward in ‘over-the-top-ness’ with Soviets assaulting the US and game being generally more colorful and cheerful. Now it is the other way around with Soviets eliminating key figure from the past instead of Allies as in RA 1 and events taking yet another direction with Empire of the Rising Sun coming out as a united threat.

The game is colorful, silly, over the top and most importantly much fun. This time the big new thing is a co-commander who can be a real person over the Internet or AI controlled. This is an interesting concept with sort of built in multiplayer, but I’m really glad they made the option of AI co-commander, helping me not deal with social interactions. On rare occasions AI glitched and never left its base, so all offensive had to be done by me. At least I didn’t have to worry about defenses. Overall having a co-commanders is very beneficial as they supply almost constant attacks on the enemy thus softening them up for my big armada, which is quickly reduced to almost nothing, because unit balance is made very well I think. In most cases you can’t storm in with dozens of Apocalypse tanks and win the level. Almost always you have to think about anti-air units since the enemy AI most often will use air units for defenses and offenses as well.

The best part from RA 2 is back – unit experience. There is nothing more satisfying than one or two units maintaining the pressure on the enemy or holding off what is thrown at you only because you previously cared and repaired them each time units were near death and now they have highest possible rank and therefore added defense and firepower. For me that was the best idea Westwood had for RA 2 and it is present in RA 3 as well

Overall I think it made a great transition from 2D to 3D and I loved the game just like the previous ones.

This game is a good game. It is a solid strategy game, and all around is decent. Not great, not terrible. The one thing that really ruins this game for me is the huge gap between the balance of units. Let me break it down for you..

There are three kinds of strategy games. The ones where the unit releationships are very simple, and it follows a rock paper scissors type format, like in Age of Mythology. Normal units beat heros, heros beats myth units, myth units beats soldiers. Then there games like Warcraft III, where (In my own opinion) the balancing is perfect, and no one unit is too overpowered or underpowered. All units are useful to the end of the game. It retains the balance of Age of Mythology but has a large unit variety. Then their are games like Red Alert.

This games unit relationships are so unbalanced its ridiculus. The infantry that you start out with are completely obsolete and worthless by the time you get your first tank; which are in turn rendered useless by the top tier units. The top tier units not only render all other units worthless (besides using them as meatshields), they also render all forms of base defense useless. Now this isn't too bad, but I am kind of a wuss when it comes to the RTS genre. I like to make a prosperous, centralized and totally self-sustaining city. Then I bully my weaker neighbors and sit back, and let everyone else fight before I start attacking my enemies in earnest. So when the enemy trains a whole crap ton of unstoppable Zepplins that fly over my city and destroy it in two seconds with me being able to do literally NOTHING, it's a little frustrating. I once destroyed the enemies entire base with a single top tier unit. And they are so powerful, that if you spam enough of them, their is absolutly nothing you can do. If a fleet of Kirov Airships or a army of King Oni storm your base, you have no options whatsoever, unless you also spam King Oni or Kirov Airships. So basically late game warfare has no varity- spam one or two units and blow up eachother with armies of mechs. Which might sound pretty sweet, but I would prefer a little more variety and strategy in the game.

In this game resources are gathered from a resource node - in eariler titles the way of gathering resources was to build refineries around a resource field. This change both slows the game while simultaniously makes the need for early expansion greater. But what this system allowed for is the advanced naval system. The system allows for a base to be built on either land or water - an interesting and surprisingly functional mechanic. But before I conclude, the biggest issue with the game is (this may or may not be resolved after this review is posted) that the multiplayer is not functional. RA3 sets its sights firmly on bringing a smile to your face. The mood of the game is enjoyably goofy and nowhere is this more evident than the completely gratuitous sexy women who practically cavort for your pleasure.  The game mechanics are no less entertaining with loads of odd military units like attack dolphins, armored blimps, and football talking troopers.  Unfortunately the units aren't quite so devastatingly useful as RA2 offered, -it's a rare thing when a single, properly managed unit can land the blows to win a game, and more's the pity.  Furthermore the superpowers are a little more niggly to obtain and less brutally satisfying.

The game plays out much more methodically than RA2 or C&C3 did so that you will have to spend more attention on individual unit tactics rather than massed forces.  This makes the game less friendly to turtle" game tactics but grants a feeling of earned superiority when you finagle the most out of your limited resources.

The Command & Conquer series were a huge part of my childhood, mainly Red Alert 2 and Yuri's Revenge, and while this game definitely has lost alot of its classic elements from back in the day, the amount of improvements it has made is finaminal.

Pros:
-Three different campaigns you can do at your own pace and difficulty
-Numerous units on sea, land and air (something that alot of RTS games don't have)
-Online Multiplayer
-After over 100 hours, I haven't found a single bug or glitch, besides occasional character movement around corners and water.
-Skrimish mode, where you can practice your strategies on AI's
-Babes, telling you what to do in the videos as you try to impress them throughout the game. Lmao.

Cons:
-Mediocre Graphics, not nearly as fancy as the videos.
-Pretty dull story mode
-The acting in the videos isn't too great, but what can you expect, right?
-Costs alot when it comes to money (and time haha)... but it's worth it, in my true opinion.

All in all, when comparing the factors I look for in a game, the pros heavily outweigh the cons the way I see it. Again, this is only my opinion, so if you can immerse yourself in another World War 2 story-mode game, then good for you man, I'm glad you enjoy it.

The Red Alert branch of the Command and Conquer games has always been close to my heart. It was the very first Red Alert that got me hooked up on computer games. Since my childhood days, the series has changed a lot and adapted new ways presenting itself. Red Alert 3 has adapted a cartoonish look, but still holding onto the important things that made the series so good. It's not perfect, but it's fun and you can share that fun with a friend. The new co-op installment is an amazing idea brought alive. Every campaign may now be played with a friend of your choosing. Red Alert 3 as a game might not revolutionize the RTS genre, but it is worth your attention especially when not coupled with a full price tag of a new game.\n\nIn conclusion, it's not perfect but it is enjoyable, and that ultimately is what games are about. Definitely looking forward to Red Alert 4.
